pullRequest.body:
As a generalisation of the division polynomials in #6703 but also possibly for other number theoretic purposes.

The recurrence relation is defined as `isEllDivSequence`, and a concrete sequence is defined as `EllDivSequence`. The fact that the two definitions are related requires a very long inductive proof, and will not be touched on in this PR.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
LGTM mostly!

It would be good to say a little bit more about how this relates to the version on wikipedia, seems equivalent to me but maybe not completely obviously so

> LGTM mostly!
> 
> It would be good to say a little bit more about how this relates to the version on wikipedia, seems equivalent to me but maybe not completely obviously so

Which definition? I believe `isEllDivSequence` is a strict generalisation of the definition in wikipedia because it allows for negative indices, whereas `EllDivSequence` is defined in two parts and I can try to explain why the private def is the correct one.

I was trying to relate the elliptic divisibility sequence on wikipedia with `EllDivSequence` yeah, and the wikipedia has
> It is not obvious, but can be proven, that the condition b | d suffices to ensure that every term in the sequence is an integer.
but yours is always integral as you have an extra `* b` in is that right? Which makes the 4th term `b * d` not `d`, thats the only difference I was thinking of

Honestly I didn't even notice that section in wikipedia! I guess my sequences lie in an arbitrary ring `R` and not `\Z`, and what's less obvious is that the truncated EDS times the extra factor of b gives the wikipedia definition - I'll add an implementation note.

Perhaps this is slightly better naming: I'll call the example `normEDS` (to be slightly shorter, and to align with the "normalised" terminology), and I'll call the `Prop`s `Ell/DivSequence` (now that there's no confusion with the example).

I also prove in `ellDivSequence_mul` that multiples of an `Ell/DivSequence` are `Ell/DivSequence`s.
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by alreadydone.

Thanks!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7616795643/job/20744380102)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7616795643/job/20744380741)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7616795643/job/20744381238)
There are some capitalization issues; please refer to [general naming conventions](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/naming.html#general-conventions).
why have this as a simp lemma? the RHS doesn't look simpler to me
Good point - I will remove this. I think the one for `odd` is similar so I'll remove that as well.
Should this say "the identity function/sequence"?
The three Props should be **I**sEll/DivSequence. The last one is good.

Should be `ellDivSequence''` according to naming convention. May be better as `ellDivSequenceAux`.
```suggestion
private def EllDivSequence'' (b c d : R) : â„• â†’ R
```
Again capitalization isn't good. Maybe `natEllDivSequence` is more indicative.
Can you use [Int.natAbs](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Init/Data/Int/Basic.html#Int.natAbs)?

Why don't you specify `h(0)` and `h(1)`? I'm not sure whether you can prove h(0) is always 0 (is it true that an EllDivSequence must be unbounded if not identically zero?), but any multiple of an EllDiv is also EllDiv, so h(1) is definitely not determined ...

Not all sequences satisfying `IsEllDivSequence` is of this form, but the ones with `h(0) = 0` supposedly are the only sequences with any arithmetic content - I don't know if they must be unbounded. Ward called those with non-zero `h(3)` and `h(4)` "general"; he called those with non-zero `h(2)*h(3)` "proper"; wikipedia calls those with `h(1) = 1` "normalised". I called these "canonical" to be deliberately vague so as to encompass all normalised sequences, including the non-general and non-proper ones, which Ward called "special". In any case I'll add both specifications.
Lemma names should be like `natEllDivSequence_zero`
How about pulling `m := n/2` and `h1` to `h4` out of the `if then else`? (I thought Lean is smart enough to infer `m<n` from `m+1<n`, but maybe not ...)
I pulled `m := n / 2` out, but I don't see an easy way to unify the termination proofs.

I'd slightly prefer `IsEllSequence`; `EllSequence` could be misunderstood as the type of all elliptic sequences. I don't know if it has become a rule but I'd add `Is` to new Prop-valued defs, even though there does exists some old defs without `Is`.
Sounds good!

This works:
```suggestion
    have h4 : m + 4 < n + 5 := Nat.lt_succ.mpr (add_le_add_right (n.div_le_self 2) 4)
    have h3 : m + 3 < n + 5 := (lt_add_one _).trans h4
    have h2 : m + 2 < n + 5 := (lt_add_one _).trans h3
    have h1 : m + 1 < n + 5 := (lt_add_one _).trans h2
    if hn : Even n then
      normEDS'' b c d (m + 4) * normEDS'' b c d (m + 2) ^ 3 * (if Even m then b ^ 4 else 1) -
        normEDS'' b c d (m + 1) * normEDS'' b c d (m + 3) ^ 3 * (if Even m then 1 else b ^ 4)
    else
      have h5 : m + 5 < n + 5 := add_lt_add_right
        (Nat.div_lt_self (Nat.odd_iff_not_even.mpr hn).pos <| Nat.lt_succ_self 1) 5
      normEDS'' b c d (m + 2) ^ 2 * normEDS'' b c d (m + 3) * normEDS'' b c d (m + 5) -
        normEDS'' b c d (m + 1) * normEDS'' b c d (m + 3) * normEDS'' b c d (m + 4) ^ 2
```
Do you prefer the current names `normEDS''`/`normEDS'` or what I suggested (`normEDSAux`/`natNormEDS`)?
I prefer my current one - I want to try to keep the capitalisation approximately the same for all three

I think `normEDSAux` doesn't interfere with capitalization?
Actually, how about `Nat.normEDSAux`, `Nat.normEDS` and `Int.normEDS` which would give access to dot notation. Plus it's a bit weird to have these in the root namespace.

I thought of doing `Nat.normEDS` as well originally, but I don't like `Int.normEDS` (since EDSs are already supposed to be indexed by `Int` by my convention - I might change this in a future PR and update this accordingly). I also don't want to these to lie in the `Nat`/`Int` namespace and allow things like `n.normEDS b c d` because the `n` should really come after (to actually look like it's indexed by `n`). I don't think this will interfere much with the rest of mathlib despite being in the root namespace. If I were to keep `normEDS'` and `normEDS`, then `normEDSAux` should really be `normEDS'Aux` (but that's a bit weird), and it's a private definition anyway so the name isn't too important.
Okay, I'm fine with the names now. If it looks okay to the maintainer @alexjbest please merge.
maintainer merge

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(NumberTheory/EllipticDivisibilitySequence): define elliptic divisibility sequences
